data.text:
Even after the New Horizons boom, I think The Sims is the larger franchise. The series has undoubtedly experienced its ups and downs, but you cannot ignore how quickly it became a phenomenon with just the original release on PC.

Animal Crossing was comparatively much more niche, especially since it was limited to only the GameCube. The Sims would rapidly have one (or more) versions on the Mac, PC, as well as all mainstream game consoles by the time Wild World launched on DS in 2005.

Animal Crossing seems to be more popular in the cultural zeitgeist now.

Don't really care about sales. By that metric, Angry Birds is more popular than Fortnite and Minecraft.

What cultural zeitgeist? What has been the conversation about AC the last two years besides "remember how well it sold the during the pandemic, and mostly only during the pandemic". I mean, Sims ain't trending on Twitter, but this place doesn't really run in those circles. People mention sales, but they also mention consistent updates and support, modding scenes (hell, there's a whole conversation about improving racial diversity through mods in Sims through more hair options and that's being said without even touching where Animal Crossing was at in terms of diversity last decade), criticisms about the game and so on.

It is what it is, I've just never seen people double down on getting such slam dunk easy question wrong. I don't hear about PUBG, but I'm not gonna argue people aren't playing and streaming it and that it's not still one of the most popular shooters. Same with League of Legends and MOBAs.

The Sims and I don't think it's even close, even post New Horizons. You will struggle to find anyone even just a teeny tiny familiar with games who doesn't know that The Sims is, even if they've been out of the loop with gaming for ages.

Speaking of which, is there a way to (legally) play The Sims 1 on modern systems without a physical copy? Last I checked it wasn't available on any digital stores but I'd really like to revisit it.

Sadly no, don't think TS1 has ever been released digitally even. Only TS3 and TS4 are easily available to buy digitally. EA is awful at supporting anything before TS4 unfortunately.

The Sims is a significantly bigger series by a large margin but I feel like they've fumbled the bag in recent years.

Meanwhile, you can walk into any Target or Walmart and you'll see Animal Crossing merch/toys/plushies/etc.

Animal Crossing is unquestionably growing bigger among kids nowadays due to AC's brand recognition but the Sims name still carries a LOT of weight in a way I think a lot of people underestimate. There hasn't been a full new numbered Sims game since the rise of the "cozy game" genre.

Whenever the Sims 5 releases, I fully expect a Fortnite level boom in popularity again. There just hasn't been a full new game since 2014 and Animal Crossing had the benefit of 2020.

A lot of posters here are weirdly hand-waving away ACNH's sales in general, or perhaps they're just unaware of how rare that kind of commercial performance and attendant pop culture moment are. Excluding pack-ins, it's the second best-selling platform exclusive of all-time, trailing only Mario Kart 8. It's sold almost double the best-selling Sony game of all-time, despite Sony's aggressive price cutting strategy. It's sold dramatically more than The Sims did even at the height of its popularity.

Given the timing of its release, it's fair to be skeptical of whether future entries will sustain that level of success. But it's been on this trajectory for a while, growing in popularity with each main installment. Even New Leaf, which was locked to a platform with an install base of around 80 million, sold 13 million copies (which, as far as I can tell, is better than any individual release in The Sims franchise outside of the original game, which sold a few million more) and was one of the best selling titles on the 3DS.
